race.name: Big Horn Gravel
race.tagline: High, rough, and lonesome. Colorado's rowdiest gravel race.

vitals.distance_options: 85 mi 'Ram's Horn Escape', 50 mi 'Little Bighorn Loop', 20 mi 'Gravel Curious'
vitals.field_size: ~500 riders (2024), growing from 250 in earlier years
vitals.registration: Online via bighornevents.com, $100-200 depending on distance
vitals.prize_purse: Dylan Johnson noted biggest podium check of his career
vitals.aid_stations: 85mi: 3 official + 1 neutral water zone. 50mi: 2 official + 1 neutral. All support is neutral - NO crews allowed on course.
vitals.cutoff_time: Checkpoint cutoffs at aid stations (exact times in rider guide)

climate.description: Late June at 7-11K ft. Chilly starts (40s-50s째F), warming to 70s-80s째F in exposed valleys. Very strong UV at altitude.
challenges: Long exposure at elevation compounds fatigue

terrain.primary: Rugged Jeep roads, singletrack, backcountry dirt
terrain.surface: 'High, rough, and lonesome' - mix of rugged singletrack, alpine mountain roads, backcountry dirt, county gravel, and rough Jeep/BLM roads. Conditions vary with weather ruts.
features: Opening 3,000 ft climb in first 13 miles

biased_opinion.summary: Big Horn Gravel is what happens when you build a gravel race for people who think gravel races aren't hard enough. The 3,000 ft opening wall, the rutted Jeep roads, the technical singletrack - this is 'aggressive Colorado gravel' that makes pros switch to hardtails. Dylan Johnson got his biggest check here. The Vegan Cyclist calls it the best gravel race you've never heard of. It won't stay unknown for long.
biased_opinion.quote: 'Just because a race is advertised as a gravel race does not necessarily mean that a gravel bike is the right bike for the job.' - Dylan Johnson
strengths: The terrain: Genuinely rowdy. Drop-bar hardtail territory.
The challenge: 10K ft at altitude with technical surfaces. Real consequences.
The obscurity (for now): Small field, big payoff, growing fast.
weaknesses: The obscurity: Not a resume race yet. Few people outside Colorado know it.
The technicality: If you've only done smooth gravel, you'll suffer.
The opening wall: Blow up in the first 13 miles and your day is ruined.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want Colorado gravel that actually hurts, Big Horn delivers. This is not a destination race for Instagram. This is a destination race for suffering.

final_verdict.one_liner: Colorado's rowdiest gravel race where the 3,000 ft opening wall and rutted Jeep roads make pros switch to hardtails.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want genuinely hard gravel racing that tests your technical skills, altitude tolerance, and pacing discipline. Big Horn is 'the best gravel race you've never heard of' - but it won't stay unknown for long. Come prepared for aggressive terrain and you'll have an unforgettable day.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Colorado altitude without the tech: SBT GRVL (champagne gravel). If you want similar rowdiness: Gunni Grinder. If you want technical but less altitude: BWR California.

logistics.airport: Eagle County Regional (EGE) - right next to Gypsum. Denver (DEN) - I-70 drive to Eagle Valley.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Gypsum is small. Many stay in Eagle, Vail, or Edwards and drive to start. Lodging fills up - 'first high-altitude race of the season' draws crowds.
logistics.food: Small town. Plan meals. Vail/Edwards have more options.
logistics.packet_pickup: Standard pre-race pickup + limited morning check-in at Gypsum Sports Complex.
logistics.parking: Gypsum Sports Complex / downtown. Big paved and gravel lots with overflow. No major complaints.

history.origin_story: Created to showcase White River National Forest gravel and bring a genuinely rough, high-country option to the early-season calendar. The Vegan Cyclist called it 'the best gravel race you've never heard of.' Dylan Johnson raced his drop bar MTB there with great success and got his biggest podium check ever.
notable_moments: Field grew from ~250 to ~500 riders by 2024
Dylan Johnson's biggest podium check of his career
Vegan Cyclist rode both courses back-to-back (130 mi / 15K vert)
Known as 'aggressive Colorado gravel' - drop-bar hardtail territory
history.reputation: The rowdiest gravel race in Colorado. More XC MTB than Midwest gravel. 'The best gravel race you've never heard of.'

course_description.character: 'A rowdy race with nearly 10,000 feet of climbing at elevation and a few miles of singletrack.' Rugged Jeep roads where 'you really need to keep your focus or you could crash pretty badly.'

suffering_zones.label: The Opening Wall
suffering_zones.desc: First 13 miles gain ~3,000 ft. The signature gut-punch that sets up your entire day. Many mid-pack riders blow up here by treating it like a short road climb instead of the opener of a 6-9 hour day.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Brutally steep, sustained opening climb on fairly rough roads

suffering_zones.label: High Jeep-Road Sector
suffering_zones.desc: Rutted and rocky. Riders report needing 'to keep your focus or you could crash pretty badly.' Fatigue + rough surface = crashes and flats.

suffering_zones.label: Final Singletrack & Berms
suffering_zones.desc: New ~2 mi downhill singletrack plus swoopy berms near finish. Even riders on hardtails call this 'rowdy' - ruts and berms testing tired handling and braking.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Technical singletrack descent on exhausted legs

course_description.signature_challenge: The opening 3,000 ft in 13 miles is the signature gut-punch. Nearly every long-course discussion references that initial climb and how it sets up the rest of your day.

logistics.explanation: Four aid stations at miles 14, 28, 45, and 69 with neutral rollout keeps basics covered, though one was moved closer to the 11,000-foot high point after feedback. Tyler Pearce called it the 'best gravel race he's ever done' after riding both distances back-to-back. Gypsum location provides on-site camping with showers but requires travel planning for most riders.

length.explanation: 85 miles with 10,000 feet of climbing hits the sweet spot - long enough for separation without becoming a death march. Michaela Thompson won the 2023 women's race by skipping the final aid station to pass Olympian Erin Huck and defending champion Alexis Skarda. Howard Grotts finished in 4:26, proving it's raceable for the elite while still punishing. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: One rider chose a mountain bike over gravel, saying 'just because a race is advertised as a gravel race does not necessarily mean that a gravel bike is the right bike for the job.' The course includes mandatory hike-a-bike sections and what organizers call 'descents that will have you begging for mercy' through technical singletrack and primitive forest roads. Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands.

elevation.explanation: 10,000 feet of climbing reaching 11,000 feet elevation delivers serious mountain punishment. The course features 'rugged singletrack, alpine mountain roads, and backcountry dirt' according to the official profile. Dylan Johnson declared it 'way harder than the Leadville 100' after finishing third, which speaks to the concentrated vertical challenge. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 82째F and lows of 49째F, with a 30% chance of rain on any given day. June brings variable conditions with morning temps potentially in the upper 30s at the 7 AM start before reaching 80+ degrees midday. Race reports note 'unlike 2022, race day dawned clear and perfect in 2023, and rider stoke was high.' Organizers warn that primitive roads 'can become mud roads' in bad weather. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 7,130 feet and topping out above 11,000 feet creates serious oxygen debt for sea-level warriors. Race founder Jake Wells positions it as 'the first opportunity to get some high-altitude racing in' for athletes training for Leadville and Crusher. The course sits in White River National Forest at elevations that separate the adapted from the struggling. Among the highest-altitude events in gravel, on par with Badlands.

adventure.explanation: The White River National Forest setting includes Spring Creek Road, Love Connector trails, and Brush Creek leading to Sylvan Lake through what co-founder Mike Brumbaugh describes as moose habitat with wildflowers. Course runs through primitive forest service roads with sections receiving 'little to no maintenance' and includes Peter Estin Hut as a landmark.

prestige.explanation: Howard Grotts won in 2023 and Eric Brunner took 2024, plus Dylan Johnson called it the 'most money I've ever won at a race' after placing third. The $2,500 winner's purse and LifeTime Grand Prix athlete interest show growing credibility, but at four years old it's still building its reputation in the gravel hierarchy.

race_quality.explanation: The clockwise direction now puts Spring Creek and Love Connector trails early 'when people are fresh and feeling good' per co-founder Mike Brumbaugh. Aid station placement has been tweaked based on rider feedback, moving one closer to the high point. Tyler Pearce's endorsement as 'best gravel race he's ever done' shows the course design is working.

experience.explanation: Bobby Julich called it 'one of the most beautiful rides that I've ever done' as an ex-Coloradan, while Dylan Johnson emphasized it was 'way harder than the Leadville 100.' The course forces bike choice anxiety - organizers note that 'no matter what you're on - you'll wish you were on a different bike at some point.'

community.explanation: Co-founder Mike Brumbaugh notes exceptional local support: 'The support we have from the community and the government is just amazing. They love the biking community and what the spirit of gravel is all about.' The race philosophy of 'everything you love about cycling, and nothing you don't' reflects their community-first approach over pure growth.

field_depth.explanation: 2025 brings Karolina Migon fresh off her Unbound Gravel win and Lauren Stephens with three Unbound 100 victories to elevate the women's field significantly. Eric Brunner and Howard Grotts have won recent editions, but depth drops quickly after the top handful - this isn't a 50-deep competitive field like major series events. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: You get 85 miles of Rocky Mountain suffering with 10,500 feet of climbing and prize money for top 5 finishers. The course delivers everything promised without inflated pricing typical of Colorado destination races. Real climbing, real technical challenges, reasonable cost.

expenses.explanation: Gypsum sits in Eagle County near Vail with Colorado mountain town pricing for June peak season. Organizers recommend minimum 38mm tires and tire liners for the 'rugged backcountry forest roads' - expect equipment costs for proper preparation. The race provides camping and facilities access, but accommodation and travel costs reflect the premium location. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.
